text:
so this is a taro in Thai we call this Bpeuak 
this is a big one this is not even a whole

one as you can see it's already cutting but 
it comes to the store sells at half like this

which is great sometimes they come in the small 
ones about this big and the difference between

the big ones and those ones is similar to the 
difference between the big potato and a small

potato the big ones are starch here the small 
taro is less starchy and it's also a little more

slimy I like to cook with the big ones because 
of the starch so you want to just peel this and

I forgot my peeler today so we're gonna do this 
with a knife so you just want to get the peel

off and if you have a peeler obviously you can 
do this by peeler this is almost faster okay

and then sometimes you get a little divot like 
that that you can't peel off you just cut it

off as much as you can't there and now so I'm 
using this for my boy my dessert so I want to

steam it but at this point you can cut it into 
cubes and boil it if you want so whatever you

want to do with it I'm going to cut into cubes 
and then just let it steam in the steamer until

you can run a fork through it easily just like 
the way you would test a pile potato wisdom so

for small things like this you can buy one 
of these steamer inserts and put it in to

a little a pot or whatever so I'm just gonna 
let it sit here and come back when it's done

so it's been about 8 to 10 minutes or so and our 
tyro is done and you can check it just sticking

a fork through it and if it goes right through 
then it's done now we're prepping this for our

boil I've desserts so all you have to do is just 
take a fork and just mash it and it doesn't need

or if you have a potato masher I guess you could 
use that too and you don't have to be completely

thoroughly fine for this dessert just as long 
as there's no big chunks then you're good to go
